Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Carbon-Nanotube-Coated Copper Wires for High Frequency Devices

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this collaborative research project is to address the grand challenge caused by the skin and proximity effects in high-frequency applications. The objective of this project is to develop copper wires coated with copper-decorated carbon nanotubes to achieve reduced energy loss and overheating in electrical and electronic devices. The research approaches include realization of copper-decorated carbon nanotubes on textured copper wires to reduce the inter-tube impedance of carbon-nanotube films, uniformly aligning carbon nanotubes on copper wires using a simple mechanical wiping method, understanding the mechanism of reduced skin and proximity effects in carbon-nanotube-coated copper wires, and reducing the energy loss and overheating using the carbon-nanotube-coated copper wires.

If successful, the results of this research will lead to significant outcomes, including controllable, aligned coating of carbon nanotubes on copper wires, fabricating robust CNT films through mechanical wiping, and carbon-nanotube-coated copper wires of high electrical and thermal conductivities for high-frequency applications. This research will impact all societal levels by revolutionizing the performance of copper wires in a wide range of applications. Practically, the proposed method is expected to provide a novel approach to reduce energy loss and heat generation in high-frequency applications. The research results will also contribute to productivity improvement, energy savings, and environmental protection in related industries that rely on high-frequency electrical signals and powers. Graduate and undergraduate students will benefit through involvement in the research and classroom instruction. The engagement of K-12 students and teachers in this project will also establish new partnerships between the universities and K-12 schools.

Institution.Name: Iowa State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of the project is to develop CNT-coated Cu wires to achieve reduced energy loss and overheating in electrical and electronic devices. The proposed research will establish a novel technology to defy the traditional difficulties in electrical and electronic devices, i.e., to improve electrical conductivity and reduce skin and proximity effects. To accomplish the goal, research efforts will focus on the following objectives: 1) Obtain uniform coating of CNT films on Cu wires, 2) Realize nanofusion of CNTs coated on Cu wires to form nanonetwork and reduce internal and contact resistance, 3) Investigate the mechanism of suppressed skin effect and proximity effect of CNT-coated Cu wires, and 4) Achieve reduced energy loss and overheating in CNT-coated Cu wires. Under tight collaboration with Oak Ridge National Lab, we have developed a technique to improve the thermal conductivity of CNTs from 39 W/mK to 754 W/mK. This will significantly enhance the heat dissipation in high-frequency electrical and electronics devices. During the project, it was realized that both carbon nanotubes and graphene-based structures are excellent candidates for coating copper wires. Also graphene-based structures provide great surface area and adhesion to the wire surface. We have studied the structure and thermal conductivity of graphene foam, graphene papers, and graphene oxide papers to assess their capacity for reducing overheating in high-frequency devices. A thermal reffusivity theory has been developed to provide excellent evaluation of the crystallite/grain size in graphene-based materials. Also a switch behavior of the very high thermal conductivity of graphene paper has been discovered when the ambient temperature is reduced to a certain level. A new anisotropic specific heat theory has been developed to interpret the phonon transport in the c-axis of graphene paper and quantitatively evaluate its very long phonon mean free path.

 

With the partial/full support of this project, five Ph.D. students have graduated (three female). Two of them (female) have become assistant professors in China universities. The three female Ph.D. have won the Research Excellent Award and the prestigious 2016 Zaffarano Prize at Iowa State University. Two current Ph.D. students have received excellent training on characterizing the thermal transport of micro/nanoscale materials. Three undergraduate students (one female) have been trained in our laboratory on microscale thermal conductivity measurement. The graduate students have presented their results on 5 international conferences. The research results were also integrated into graduate level Heat Transfer (ME536) teaching. With the full/partial support of this project, 21 papers have been published/accepted for publication in highly visible journals. They are also listed on the PI’s lab web for broader access. Lab tours have been arranged for high school students, undergraduate students, and graduate students, and to provide hand-on experience for them on micro/nanoscale material characterization and measurement.

 

 


Last Modified: 11/03/2017
Modified by: Xinwei Wang
